awd_titl_txt: A National Introductory Colloquium and Undergraduate Research Experience in Mathematical Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
This program will provide virtual colloquia for students at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) that include robust scientific discussions and interactions between the speaker and the students and between the students at the different HBCUs. Additionally, this proposal aims to impact both the students and the faculty members at HBCUs. By engaging the HBCU faculty members as partners in the project, the goal is to create pipelines for the HBCU students to graduate schools and to establish and enhance working relationships and networking between HBCU faculty members and faculty members at large research institutions. If these two innovative ideas are successful, they will have a broad impact. This research project emphasizes mathematical biology, but the same ideas should work in other branches of pure and applied mathematics, and in other scientific disciplines as well. In making the virtual colloquia as interactive as a classroom, the project will have created a template for faculty at other research universities to participate in and enhance the training of undergraduates at HBCUs, and that, in and of itself, will create pipelines from the HBCUs to the research institutions, both for students and for faculty. The methods and the template could then be used by other groups of mathematicians or scientists to enhance the training of students at the other HBCUs at low cost.

The project has three goals: to encourage undergraduate students at the HBCUs to go to graduate school in the STEM disciplines; to connect faculty in analysis and mathematical biology at the HBCUs to faculty and research programs at The Ohio State University (OSU) and other large research institutions; to experiment with virtual colloquia and virtual teaching techniques in mathematics. Faculty members at six HBCUs will each recruit 2-3 students to participate in the year-long program that includes a meet-and-greet workshop at Howard University, where they will meet the PIs and some of the speakers and hear mathematical biology lectures. Through the academic year, the students receive 7 introductory colloquia in which the speakers sit in their home office and the broadband facilities of the Mathematical Biosciences Institute (MBI) are used to broadcast the colloquium simultaneously to the six HBCUs. The MBI facilities permit questions and answers and discussions in real time during the talk. Materials prepared by the speakers provide follow-up activities that will be mentored by the local faculty members. The year concludes with a 10-day workshop at OSU that will be both a research experience for the students and collaboration events for the faculty. For the students, there will be panel discussions on academic and non-academic jobs and graduate school. For faculty research engagement, ten mathematical biology faculty members at OSU, in addition to some speakers, have agreed to include an HBCU faculty member in their current research program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This program aimed to form a network involving students and faculty at six Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) and faculty at large research institutions to increase participation in mathematics including graduate education and research projects. The project aimed to impact both the students and the faculty members at HBCUs. By engaging the HBCU faculty members as partners in the project, the goal was to create pipelines for the HBCU students to graduate schools and to establish and enhance working relationships and networking between HBCU faculty members and faculty members at large research institutions.

The program provided virtual colloquia for students at six HBCUs that included robust scientific discussions and interactions between the speaker and the students and between the students at the different HBCUs. Speakers were instructed to begin their talk by describing their own career path, so students could see that there are many routes to progress through degrees and to find one’s mathematical calling.  After each colloquium, the participating HBCU faculty member held at least one meeting with local participating students, discussing the talk and working through exercises that were often provided by the speaker. A week or so after the colloquium, the speaker returned for a virtual follow-up meeting, an opportunity for open discussion that ranged from delving further into the lecture topic to graduate school and career advice to internship opportunities.

The project had three goals: 1. to encourage undergraduate students at the HBCUs to go to graduate school in the STEM disciplines; 2. to connect faculty in analysis and mathematical biology at the HBCUs to faculty and research programs at The Ohio State University (OSU) and other large research institutions; 3. to experiment with virtual colloquia and virtual teaching techniques in mathematics.

Participating students shared that the program solidified or increased their interest in enrolling in a graduate program; in particular they noted that they learned that graduate school was a more feasible option than they had expected, so they could now see a path to an advanced degree. Some of the inaugural participants are already in graduate programs at this time; others are currently applying to programs.

The proposal was submitted before the pandemic, at a time when such virtual meetings were not well established. The pandemic delayed implementation of the program to a time when such meetings were fairly routine. However, forming and strengthening personal relationships amongst groups of individuals in such meetings remains challenging, requiring intention, planning, and effort. The incorporation of in-person events greatly aided the formation of meaningful and stable relationships and was viewed as an important aspect of the program.

Because the project was funded at a reduced level, we were unable to include the opening workshop, though we did observe that it would have been valuable in forming cross-institute connections that would have been meaningful to have in place through the academic year and virtual meetings.

The workshop at OSU at the end of year one was highly impactful for participants, although not all students or participating faculty members were able to attend. Students were enthusiastic about the projects led by OSU graduate students, panel discussions with OSU graduate students and with individuals showcasing different types of employment available with advanced degrees in mathematical sciences, and inspiring lectures by OSU faculty members.

This program emphasized mathematical biology, but the same ideas should work in other branches of pure and applied mathematics, and in other scientific disciplines as well. Indeed, participating faculty thought the program offered a good model for early mathematical research engagement more generally, not only for this target audience. Three participating faculty members produced a publication to this effect and providing some program materials and video links.

While the project was funded for a single year, being able to continue key aspects through a second academic year with continuing participation of non-graduating students allowed us to observe the benefits of deepening relationships with multi-year participation by students and faculty. This program has led to some lasting research collaborations involving HBCU faculty, HBCU students, and faculty at large research institutions. Some of the research involving participating students is expected to result in publications.

This project has had a clear positive impact on a group of students and faculty and merits ongoing operation. It was funded as a pilot program, so organizers will need to reformulate with lessons learned before seeking other avenues of support.
